primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God calls existence out of non-existence and life out of death, independent of human capacity or imagination.

subject.identificatie: God (The Creator/The One who raises the dead)
tekstueel_bewijs: God who gives life to the dead and calls into existence the things that do not exist
The Lord who made the earth, the Lord who formed it
God is the One who will reveal great and hidden things

object.identificatie: New Life / Hope beyond human hope / Revelation of hidden things
tekstueel_bewijs: great and hidden things which you have not known
life where there is no breath
hope where there is no hope

zender.identificatie: The Divine Nature/The Word of the Lord
tekstueel_bewijs: The word of the Lord came to Jeremiah

ontvanger.identificatie: Abraham, Jeremiah, the Hearer, the Dead
tekstueel_bewijs: Abraham ... is the father of us all
the Lord will gather in the harvest of all those who have hoped in him
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of a hope they cannot generate.

tekstueel_bewijs: Faith is called into being by the Word of the Lord
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject; His Word is the Helper.
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicitly the power working in us (Ephesians 3:20).

tegenstander.identificatie: Death, Non-existence, Human Limitation, False Hope
tekstueel_bewijs: our idea of what to hope for is limited by our human horizons
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a bad mood but 'the void' and 'death' itself, which only a Creator can overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of 'hoping against hope' and loosening the grip on small, human-defined hopes.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (Abraham/Hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: Human faith is a secondary reaction called into being by the primary action of God's Word.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God's Character → New Life/Hope → The Hopeless

voorbeelden_god_subject: God gives life to the dead
The Lord who made the earth
God is the One who was already there
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we learn to loosen our grip
we think we know what we want

voorbeelden: All of that has to go (referring to small hopes)
We think we know what we want
great and hidden things which you have not known
God who is powerful to call into existence
power working in us can do infinitely more
nothing anyone can do (human lack of power)

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is a 'Power-endowment' event. It emphasizes the total lack of human 'Pouvoir' (ability) in the face of death and the absolute 'Pouvoir' of God to create from nothing.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Hopelessness) to ~S1 (Generic Hope/Spring) to expose its insufficiency, then to S1 (The God who raises the dead).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'Subject-switch': Hope is not a human attribute but a divine act.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The sermon explicitly mentions suicide, catastrophic loss, and the 'grip of ice' of death.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon explicitly rejects faith as a human work or 'instrumental' helper. It places God as the sole Subject of the resurrection and the creator of faith itself.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Abraham ... is the father of us all

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: It’s not Abraham’s faith that counts, but Abraham’s God.
Life has simply vanished beyond recall... Into this void the apostle speaks.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The preacher explicitly deconstructs exemplarism by stating it wasn't Abraham's faith that mattered, but the God who acted upon him.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: God is the one who calls their faith into being; they are receivers of the Word.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of 'generating' faith; comfort in the face of absolute loss.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative is tightly focused on the ontological gap between human 'nothingness' and divine 'being'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the eternal God who raises the dead

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (via the Word) creates the 'Vouloir' and 'Pouvoir' where they are absent.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin/Death is seen as a total void/hopelessness that humans cannot bridge.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject. It avoids the 'Helper' trap where God merely assists human effort.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for a Lent/Easter context.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon already balances the 'Devoir' of loosening our grip as a consequence of God's 'Pouvoir'.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God raises the dead) correctly precedes and enables Ethics (loosening our grip).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in theocentric preaching. The structural 'engine' of the sermon perfectly matches the surface language of grace.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the use of Dante or the 'grip of ice' metaphor, Greimasian analysis reveals that the preacher has structurally replaced the 'Human Subject' with the 'Divine Subject' at the level of the narrative engine.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains what Romans 4 meant; this analysis shows how the sermon functions as a 'speech act' to re-create the hearer as a Receiver.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Subject-switch'—moving the hearer from a failed Subject (trying to hope) to a Receiver (being given hope).

appendices.notities: The sermon is a classic example of Fleming Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace'.
